prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: H2O-18
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Optically thin H2O-18 observations towards G327 and IRAS16065

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
We selected the H2O-18 4_14-3_21 line at 390.6~GHz in band 8 for this ALMA high resolution follow up. It has comparable transmission as the 322.5~GHz line, but is lower in energy and potential line blending by ethyl cyanide in two of the sources can be accounted for (see Figure in proposal and the method used in Marseille et al. 2010) while the 322.5~GHz line is blended with an unknown line. Even when the 203GHz becomes available in Cycle 4, it will have a blending problem (again Marseille et al. 2010).
For the water line, we aim at a spectral resolution of 0.4km/s, enough to clearly resolve the lines with typical width in single dish observations of 4-8km/s that might become smaller at higher angular resolution. Clearly resolving the line is also important to address potential line blending and to study in detail the kinematics of the cores.
In our APEX observations the water lines are clearly detected all proposed sources (Figure 2) and have fluxes of about 20-30Jy. Distributing this flux in the worst case evenly into a source of 1arcsec size (see Table 2) and asking for signal-to-noise of 10, we need to reach a noise level of about 0.04Jy/beam. We expect to resolve the morphology of the hot cores, hence towards the peaks the signal-to-noise will be higher.

For the water line, we aim at a spectral resolution of 0.4km/s, enough to clearly resolve the lines with typical width in single dish observations of 4-8km/s that might become smaller at higher angular resolution. Clearly resolving the line is also important to address potential line blending and to study in detail the kinematics of the cores.
Covering many lines of C2H5CN is crucial to properly assess and correct for a potential blend of C2H5CN with the H2O-18 line. In the other sideband, the large variety of CH3CN J=22-21 is key, together with the CH3OH observations in Band 9, to improve the physical models of the observed sources. For the non-H2O-18 windows, a lower velocity resolution of 0.8 km/s is sufficient.These lines will provide a legacy on their own. All these lines will be an important complement to the water observations, helping to constrain the physical and chemical conditions of the cores.

As explained in the justification of the correlator setup, lines from a variety of molecules, in particular CH3CN and C2H5CN, need to be spectroscopically resolved to study the kinematics and to account for possible blends with the water line. These lines come in multiplets covering a large bandwidths, hence we need to cover a large fraction of the receiver bandpass and ask for observations with high datarates. These additional lines will provide also a legacy on their own.

From modelling of high excitation lines of methyl cyanide and its 13C isotopologue observed with APEX we get typical source sizes of the high temperature components of the core of 1~arcsec, hence we aim at angular resolution of 0.15~arcsec to clearly resolve the cores. These CH_3CN lines will also be covered in the ALMA setup in the USB. In Table 2 we give the sizes expected at the temperatures of water evaporation (100K) and high temperture chemistry (230K) for a simple power law temperature distribution dictated by the luminosity of the sources (Goldreich & Kwan 1974) resulting in sizes of 1" for 100K and sizes that will fill the ALMA synthesized beam at 230~K. Note for expected cluster formation, this temperature will be distributed in a larger region and more patchy.
Another indication of a typical 1 arcsec size comes from the physical models of Rolffs et al. for the sources. They reach temperatures of 200K at radii of 0.5arcsec. We computed RATRAN water data cubes using these models and observed them with the ALMA simulator, again showing about 1arcsec as the size scale. Note, that fragmentation and/or disks will likely lead to further substructure on this scale. ATCA 3mm observations of the sources with 2arcsec resolution clearly show compact emission (Wyrowski et al. 2008; Dedes et al. 2011) towards the hot cores.

The water line at 658~GHz, which is the vibrationally excited equivalent of the ortho-water ground state line at 556.9~GHz, will be observed in Band 9. No blending lines from other abundant species could be found at this frequency.
From the rotational diagram analysis we show in the proposal, the line could in principle be also originate from an about 200K component of the core, but given it high excitation, it will likely be more compact, we assume here 0.5arcsec as an upper limit. We ask for beam matched observations between band 8 and 9, hence a synthezized beam of 0.15arcsec also in band 9. Two sources have already been tentatively detected in the line with APEX while in the other two sources we only get upper limits of about 15Jy. Assuming 10Jy and distributing the flux evenly into 0.5arcsec with the requirement of a S/N of 10, we need to reach 0.1Jy/beam. The spectral resolution of 0.5km/s is sufficient to resolve the lines with widths of 4-8km/s. Calibration on the long baselines can be aided by self-calibration on the strong dust continuum of the hot cores.

As an additional optically thin probe of water, we cover also at 658.5Ghz the H2O-17 5_32-4_41 line. Furthermore, C18O 6-5 and a bright multiplet of SO2 with a range of excitation will be covered, providing the sulphur chemistry complement to our water observations. In the other sideband C17O (6-5) as well as the bands from J=14-13 highly excited methanol in ground and torsionally excited states are observed. The methanol lines have energies from about 300 to 1000K above ground, hence complement ideally the observations of vibrationally excited water and the methyl and ethyl cyanide observations in band 8. The optically thin C17O will measure as a reference the CO column density. All these lines will be an important complement to the water observations, helping to constrain the physical and chemical conditions of the cores.

In the correlator setup we explained the importance to cover complementary molecules such as SO2, CH3OH, C18O and C17O. Since the former once come in multiplets a large bandwidths needs to be covered. Therefore we ask for the high data rates. Those additional molecular lines will provide a legacy on their own.

We expect the vibrationally excited line that is 2360~K above ground to be more compact than our estimates of about 1 arcsec for the H2O-18 lines in the Band 8 setup. We ask for beam matched observations between band 8 and 9, hence a synthezized beam of 0.15arcsec also in band 9. In Table 2 of the proposal, we give the sizes expected at the temperatures of water high temperture chemistry (230K) for a simple power law temperature distribution dictated by the luminosity of the sources (Goldreich & Kwan 1974) resulting in sizes of 0.12 to 0.36" that are well filling the ALMA synthesized beam. Note for expected cluster formation, this temperature will be distributed in a larger region and more patchy, e.g. leading to several centers of vibrationally excited water emission.

We selected the H2O-18 4_14-3_21 line at 390.6~GHz in band 8 for this ALMA high resolution follow up. It has comparable transmission as the 322.5~GHz line, but is lower in energy and potential line blending by ethyl cyanide in two of the sources can be accounted for (see Figure in proposal and the method used in Marseille et al. 2010) while the 322.5~GHz line is blended with an unknown line. Even when the 203GHz becomes available in Cycle 4, it will have a blending problem (again Marseille et al. 2010).
For the water line, we aim at a spectral resolution of 0.4km/s, enough to clearly resolve the lines with typical width in single dish observations of 4-8km/s that might become smaller at higher angular resolution. Clearly resolving the line is also important to address potential line blending and to study in detail the kinematics of the cores.
In our APEX observations the water lines are clearly detected all proposed sources (Figure 2) and have fluxes of about 20-30Jy. Distributing this flux in the worst case evenly into a source of 1arcsec size (see Table 2) and asking for signal-to-noise of 10, we need to reach a noise level of about 0.04Jy/beam. We expect to resolve the morphology of the hot cores, hence towards the peaks the signal-to-noise will be higher.

For the water line, we aim at a spectral resolution of 0.4km/s, enough to clearly resolve the lines with typical width in single dish observations of 4-8km/s that might become smaller at higher angular resolution. Clearly resolving the line is also important to address potential line blending and to study in detail the kinematics of the cores.
Covering many lines of C2H5CN is crucial to properly assess and correct for a potential blend of C2H5CN with the H2O-18 line. In the other sideband, the large variety of CH3CN J=22-21 is key, together with the CH3OH observations in Band 9, to improve the physical models of the observed sources. For the non-H2O-18 windows, a lower velocity resolution of 0.8 km/s is sufficient.These lines will provide a legacy on their own. All these lines will be an important complement to the water observations, helping to constrain the physical and chemical conditions of the cores.

As explained in the justification of the correlator setup, lines from a variety of molecules, in particular CH3CN and C2H5CN, need to be spectroscopically resolved to study the kinematics and to account for possible blends with the water line. These lines come in multiplets covering a large bandwidths, hence we need to cover a large fraction of the receiver bandpass and ask for observations with high datarates. These additional lines will provide also a legacy on their own.

From modelling of high excitation lines of methyl cyanide and its 13C isotopologue observed with APEX we get typical source sizes of the high temperature components of the core of 1~arcsec, hence we aim at angular resolution of 0.15~arcsec to clearly resolve the cores. These CH_3CN lines will also be covered in the ALMA setup in the USB. In Table 2 we give the sizes expected at the temperatures of water evaporation (100K) and high temperture chemistry (230K) for a simple power law temperature distribution dictated by the luminosity of the sources (Goldreich & Kwan 1974) resulting in sizes of 1" for 100K and sizes that will fill the ALMA synthesized beam at 230~K. Note for expected cluster formation, this temperature will be distributed in a larger region and more patchy.
Another indication of a typical 1 arcsec size comes from the physical models of Rolffs et al. for the sources. They reach temperatures of 200K at radii of 0.5arcsec. We computed RATRAN water data cubes using these models and observed them with the ALMA simulator, again showing about 1arcsec as the size scale. Note, that fragmentation and/or disks will likely lead to further substructure on this scale. SMA mm observations of the sources with 1-2arcsec resolution clearly show compact emission (Hunter et al. 2006; Leurini et al. 2011) towards the main hot cores.

The water line at 658~GHz, which is the vibrationally excited equivalent of the ortho-water ground state line at 556.9~GHz, will be observed in Band 9. No blending lines from other abundant species could be found at this frequency.
From the rotational diagram analysis we show in the proposal, the line could in principle be also originate from an about 200K component of the core, but given it high excitation, it will likely be more compact, we assume here 0.5arcsec as an upper limit. We ask for beam matched observations between band 8 and 9, hence a synthezized beam of 0.15arcsec also in band 9. Two sources have already been tentatively detected in the line with APEX while in the other two sources we only get upper limits of about 15Jy. Assuming 10Jy and distributing the flux evenly into 0.5arcsec with the requirement of a S/N of 10, we need to reach 0.1Jy/beam. The spectral resolution of 0.5km/s is sufficient to resolve the lines with widths of 4-8km/s. Calibration on the long baselines can be aided by self-calibration on the strong dust continuum of the hot cores.

As an additional optically thin probe of water, we cover also at 658.5Ghz the H2O-17 5_32-4_41 line. Furthermore, C18O 6-5 and a bright multiplet of SO2 with a range of excitation will be covered, providing the sulphur chemistry complement to our water observations. In the other sideband C17O (6-5) as well as the bands from J=14-13 highly excited methanol in ground and torsionally excited states are observed. The methanol lines have energies from about 300 to 1000K above ground, hence complement ideally the observations of vibrationally excited water and the methyl and ethyl cyanide observations in band 8. The optically thin C17O will measure as a reference the CO column density. All these lines will be an important complement to the water observations, helping to constrain the physical and chemical conditions of the cores.

In the correlator setup we explained the importance to cover complementary molecules such as SO2, CH3OH, C18O and C17O. Since the former once come in multiplets a large bandwidths needs to be covered. Therefore we ask for the high data rates. Those additional molecular lines will provide a legacy on their own.

We expect the vibrationally excited line that is 2360~K above ground to be more compact than our estimates of about 1 arcsec for the H2O-18 lines in the Band 8 setup. We ask for beam matched observations between band 8 and 9, hence a synthezized beam of 0.15arcsec also in band 9. In Table 2 of the proposal, we give the sizes expected at the temperatures of water high temperture chemistry (230K) for a simple power law temperature distribution dictated by the luminosity of the sources (Goldreich & Kwan 1974) resulting in sizes of 0.12 to 0.36" that are well filling the ALMA synthesized beam. Note for expected cluster formation, this temperature will be distributed in a larger region and more patchy, e.g. leading to several centers of vibrationally excited water emission.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Water controls the chemistry of many other molecular species. It is a unique diagnostic of warm gas and energetic processes taking place during star formation. Observations of water was one of the key science themes of the Herschel space mission. However within the 10-40 arcsec FWHM of Herschel, the water emission regions remain unresolved. Fortunately, some high-excitation lines of water and its rare 18O isotopologue can be observed from the exceptional ALMA high site. In particular, it will be possible to spatially resolve the hot inner envelope of massive proto-clusters in which water is evaporated from the ice mantles of dust grains. In these regions water might rival CO in abundance and with its many lines of high excitation, will provide a new tool to study the inner workings of massive star forming regions, in particular their water abundances, excitation, velocity structure and morphology (disk vs. envelope components), thereby crucially enhancing the value of the water observations we obtained with Herschel/HIFI with high resolution ALMA images of optically thin and high excitation lines.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2013.1.01187.S Hot water in the inner envelope of massive proto-stars/clusters Wyrowski

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: SRON Groningen, SRON Netherlands Institute for Space Research
